text:
<@U01PJ5YMFBJ> To get you started at Michael's question:

"At the trivial level it looks easy: Do half of all bets at 2 win? But when you think about it it's not that simple."

What if the market (best back/lay) is at 2.0 / 10.0, and you get matched at 2.0. How often do you win?

What if the market is 1.5 / 2.0. How often do you win?

If people have been telling you to trade standard technical analysis nonsense, they might try to categorise strategies into mean reverting and trend following. But they don't point out that if you are constantly crossing the back/lay spread without good fundamental reason, then you're probably going to lose.

user_profile.real_name: Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon
user_profile.name: fcmisc

elements.text:
To get you started at Michael's question:

"At the trivial level it looks easy: Do half of all bets at 2 win? But when you think about it it's not that simple."

What if the market (best back/lay) is at 2.0 / 10.0, and you get matched at 2.0. How often do you win?

What if the market is 1.5 / 2.0. How often do you win?

If people have been telling you to trade standard technical analysis nonsense, they might try to categorise strategies into mean reverting and trend following. But they don't point out that if you are constantly crossing the back/lay spread without good fundamental reason, then you're probably going to lose.

text: <@U01PJ5YMFBJ> I can`t help feeling that on your journey you have missed out taking some fundamental steps to understand how the market works and think that coming up with a horse racing model(s) is the solution. This is what helped me, setting up BA to display just money moving and how it looks as a %. Just a case then of recording a load of races, look when the odds move, rewind a few secs to see what caused the move and write it down. Then look for some links in what you have scribbled. Rinse and repeat then test and tweak. This was the template I used. Model at the end not the beginning.

elements.text: I can`t help feeling that on your journey you have missed out taking some fundamental steps to understand how the market works and think that coming up with a horse racing model(s) is the solution. This is what helped me, setting up BA to display just money moving and how it looks as a %. Just a case then of recording a load of races, look when the odds move, rewind a few secs to see what caused the move and write it down. Then look for some links in what you have scribbled. Rinse and repeat then test and tweak. This was the template I used. Model at the end not the beginning.

text: So backtest data on horses at 2/10, and see how often they actually won, then offer a price i think is value based on that answer?

elements.text: So backtest data on horses at 2/10, and see how often they actually won, then offer a price i think is value based on that answer?

text: and also bear in mind, with the absence of other information, if the price of a single runner is 2/10 it doesn't mean 2 isn't great value...you need to consider the other runners too. The only thing you can state with certainty is that if you get filled (backing) closer to the lay price (i.e. nearer 10) it is better value than merely taking the available back price (2)...however without further information its not guaranteed you would be placing a +ev bet...

elements.text: and also bear in mind, with the absence of other information, if the price of a single runner is 2/10 it doesn't mean 2 isn't great value...you need to consider the other runners too. text: <@U025B8CJH3J> has joined the channel

So as <@UBS7QANF3> points out that article relates to 2 academic articles about bookmaker efficiency. I can read one, and I basically says bookmakers are generally efficient, no fav or long shot bias.
So Betfair is however a different crowd, its pro gamblers, traders, bots,..
So what does this tell me? Not a lot really..
Ive determined fair price is mostly in the spread somewhere at any given time
So to be profitable you need to offer the value side of that fair price, and if hedging  get out that same side with an offer

So to be profitable you need to offer the value side of that fair price, and if hedging  get out that same side with an offer

text: And in terms of the exchange, i think you need to define efficiency. Even the exchange may actually be pretty far off from showing you the true probabilites at the off. But what it does rather well is reflecting what the crowd thinks. This is surely still beatable with a very solid fundamental approach, but its gonna be hard and you (and me) are probably far off from being able to predict true prices better than bsp

text: Regarding hedging, I assumed before coming here that most 'traders' were looking for models that got in and out of bets (best case laying below true odds and backing above), from reading back and the last couple of days talk it appears thats not the case, so when backtesting are the majority testing against the races result? (placing x number of bets that meet their criteria pre off and ‘letting them ride’) Im interested in the pre off guys as thats where I will be starting.

text: I'll go against the grain, but with the condition that you are a newbie, I think all newbie should hedge. In the long run its a no no. When you are learning it will help you focus on beating bsp and you are very very likely to make mistakes which are amplified massively when betting

With my current strategy i have a sub optimal hedge at schedules off, mainly just offering a hedge bet at reverse price with market_on_close 
But I'm thinking i need to more comparison with bsp, as the auction can change the price to a certain extent and im not achieving full value i may have ascertained with the original bet

text: I don't know if they are more corrupt, but as an example, when you bet into races in South Australia, you have to take into account that jockeys may work together to prevent others from getting a run.  Let's call this anecdotal, but was passed on to me by a form analyst and i then noticed in happen in certain races once I knew what I was looking for.  I'm sure it happens elsewhere, but South Oz races seem to have a worse reputation.  Races in the country are often suspect also and I doubt any state has a worse reputation than Queensland.

elements.text: I don't know if they are more corrupt, but as an example, when you bet into races in South Australia, you have to take into account that jockeys may work together to prevent others from getting a run.  Let's call this anecdotal, but was passed on to me by a form analyst and i then noticed in happen in certain races once I knew what I was looking for.  I'm sure it happens elsewhere, but South Oz races seem to have a worse reputation.  Races in the country are often suspect also and I doubt any state has a worse reputation than Queensland.
